Introduction

Tinea versicolor, also known as pityriasis versicolor, is a superficial fungal infection of the skin caused by Malassezia species (eg, M globosa, M furfur).  Although typically benign, tinea versicolor can cause cosmetic concerns due to its characteristic skin discoloration.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The pathogenesis of tinea versicolor starts with the overgrowth of Malassezia species, which are nondermatophytic, lipid-dependent yeasts.  These yeasts are part of normal skin flora and proliferate under certain conditions, such as increased sebum production, warm temperatures, and high humidity.  They colonize the stratum corneum and interfere with pigment transfer to keratinocytes.  The affected skin does not tan when exposed to the sun, leading to the characteristic hypopigmented patches seen in tinea versicolor.



Several factors predispose patients to tinea versicolor, including:



  • Hot and humid climates
  • Excessive sweating
  • Oily skin
  • Hormonal changes (eg, puberty, pregnancy)
  • Immunocompromised states (eg, HIV, organ transplantation, chronic corticosteroid use)

Clinical presentation



Tinea versicolor is characterized by well-circumscribed macules that can be hypopigmented (

image 1
) (most common), hyperpigmented (
image 2
), or erythematous (
image 3
) (hence the name "versicolor"); they often coalesce and are covered with fine scales.  The scales become more apparent when the affected skin is stretched or scraped.  Tinea versicolor most commonly affects the upper trunk and extremities, likely due to greater sebum production in these areas.  Mild pruritus can occur, but most patients are asymptomatic.

Diagnosis



Tinea versicolor is diagnosed clinically with microscopic examination of skin scrapings.  Skin scrapings with potassium hydroxide preparation showing hyphae and yeast cells with a spaghetti-and-meatballs appearance (

image 4
) are diagnostic of tinea versicolor.  Wood lamp examination reveals yellow to yellow-green fluorescence of affected areas in fewer than half of cases; if present, this finding is nonspecific and supports, but does not confirm, the diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for tinea versicolor includes:



  • Seborrheic dermatitis (
    image 5
    ):  an inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous patches with oily scales that commonly affect areas with a high density of sebaceous glands, such as the scalp and face.  In contrast to tinea versicolor, involvement of the chest is less common, and scales are thicker (when present).
  • Vitiligo (
    image 6
    ):  an acquired disorder characterized by well-circumscribed patches of depigmented (not hypopigmented) skin without scaling due to autoimmune-mediated destruction of melanocytes.
  • Pityriasis rosea:  an acute, self-limiting skin condition characterized by oval, erythematous patches with a fine collarette of scale in a Christmas tree pattern (
    figure 1
    ) on the trunk.  Unlike tinea versicolor, pityriasis rosea typically presents with a herald patchâ€”a larger, solitary lesion preceding the eruption of smaller lesions.  Pityriasis rosea is associated with viral, not fungal, infection.
  • Secondary syphilis (
    image 7
    ):  possibly, a generalized macular rash.  In contrast to tinea versicolor, the rash of secondary syphilis often involves the palms and soles and is associated with other symptoms, such as fever and lymphadenopathy.

Management



Management of tinea versicolor includes topical ketoconazole, which limits the production of fungal cell membrane components by inhibiting cytochrome P450 enzymes.  Topical terbinafine and selenium sulfide can also be used.  In addition to using antifungal therapy, avoiding excessive sun exposure may make tinea versicolor less noticeable.

Prognosis



Patients with tinea versicolor generally experience resolution of symptoms and restoration of normal skin pigmentation within weeks to months of starting treatment.  However, recurrence is common, especially in predisposed individuals.

Summary
